DOC.HEAD: Traffic Accidents Claim 353 Lives Over Christmas Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Accidents on the nation's roads and highways claimed 353 lives during the four-day Christmas weekend, but the death toll was lower than last year's. California had the highest number of fatalities with 48, followed by Texas with 28 and Florida with 27. The death toll was well within estimates made by the Chicago-based National Safety Council, which had predicted that from 320 to 420 people would die in traffic accidents during the holiday weekend. The official counting period began at 6 p.m. local time Friday and ended at 11:59 p.m. local time Monday. The council said its estimates were based on data from previous years, seasonal weather factors and national driving safety trends. During last year's Christmas holiday, 386 traffic fatalities were reported. For the New Year's holiday period, the council estimates that between 250 and 350 people could die in road accidents, compared with 317 last year. The New Year's counting period begins at 6 p.m. local time Friday and runs through 11:59 p.m. local time Monday.
